text: Tummy time is essential! Place your baby on their tummy for short periods while awake to strengthen neck and shoulder muscles.
Encourage sitting by placing toys just out of reach. Use pillows for support if needed, but let them practice balancing.
Create a safe, open space for crawling. Place interesting objects a few feet away to motivate them to move forward.
To encourage walking, let your child hold onto sturdy furniture (cruising) or hold their hands while they take steps. Avoid baby walkers.
Provide stacking blocks, large puzzles, and scribbling materials to refine fine motor control and hand-eye coordination.
Talk to your baby constantly! Narrate your day, respond to their coos and gurgles, and make eye contact while speaking.
Read simple picture books together. Point to objects and name them clearly. Encourage them to imitate sounds like 'ma-ma' or 'da-da'.
Expand on your child's words. If they say 'car', you say 'Yes, a fast red car!'. This helps build their vocabulary.
Give simple one-step commands like 'Pick up the ball' to practice receptive language skills. Praise them when they follow through.
Smile back at your baby! Mimic their facial expressions and sounds to build a strong emotional bond and social awareness.
Play peek-a-boo and hide-and-seek with toys. This teaches object permanence and social interaction turns.
Arrage playdates with other children. Even if they engage in 'parallel play' (playing side-by-side), it's a crucial social step.
Ensure your baby gets plenty of sleep and a balanced diet (breastmilk/formula and solids as appropriate) for healthy growth.
Create a routine! Consistent meal and bedtimes provide a sense of security and help regulate your toddler's behavior.
Every child develops at their own pace. If you have specific concerns, please consult a pediatrician. Keep engaging with your child through play and talk!
